awd_titl_txt: NRT-DESE: Training in Data-Driven Discovery - From the Earth and the Universe to the Successful Careers of the Future
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award prepares master's and doctoral students at Northwestern University with the data-analysis skills to advance the research frontiers in astronomy, physics, and Earth science.  While providing students with training in data-enabled science and engineering, the program promotes collaborations with research and education that will lead to the development of new data tools with broad applicability.  Through internships, evidence-based curricular approaches, and capstone citizen science projects, trainees will develop the core competencies in demand by a wide range of employers.  Trainees will learn how to effectively engage the public in discoveries on the solar system, stellar explosions, star clusters and galaxies, gravitational waves, and seismic waves.  The citizen science projects will be used for innovative recruiting, strengthening the participation of the public and students from underrepresented groups. By diversifying the graduate student population and improving instruction and mentoring, the research will be contributing to a diverse, inclusive scientific workforce in academia and industry.

This program will bridge computer science, electrical engineering, applied math, and statistics to physics, astronomy, and Earth sciences in order to develop students with the skills required to analyze datasets of unprecedented size and complexity.  Trainees will be prepared for the technical challenges of extensive data generated at major research equipment and facilities, including Large Syntopic Survey Telescope, Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory, and EarthScope.  Trainees will learn data analytics and management, statistical methods, and image processing skills to ask new questions and choose the appropriate tools from the method disciplines and adapt them to solve problems in physics, astronomy, and Earth sciences. The program will also prepare students to work in a collaborative scientific community, advancing their leadership, communication, mentoring, and management skills.  Internships at major research facilities, national laboratories, and the private sector will help students gain transferrable professional skills to pursue a range of career paths.

por.por_cntn:
Integrated Data-Driven Discovery in Earth and Astrophyical Sciences (IDEAS) is a program funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), with support from the Center for Interdisciplinary Exploration and Research in Astrophysics (CIERA) and Northwestern University. The purpose of this project is to train graduate students for research and work in interdisciplinary fields, particularly data-enabled science and engineering (DESE), such as physics and astronomy, earth and planetary sciences, computer science, electrical engineering, applied mathematics, and statistics. IDEAS has 4 major goals. Interdisciplinary training aims to provide students with the technical knowledge and skills necessary to collaborate with other disciplines (Goal 1). The project also intends to increase students' transferrable professional skills such as leadership, collaboration, and communication skills (Goal 2). Additionally, the IDEAS project seeks to contribute to DESE workforce development through professional development activities, including internships and coursework (Goal 3). The project's final goal is to enhance institutional capacity for research and education (Goal 4).  Each goal is supported by the following specific objectives: 

Objectives related to Goal 1: Knowledge and Technical Skills 

  • Increase students' interdisciplinary knowledge/research skills  

  • Achieve progress toward scientific discoveries 

  • Increased opportunities for student application of knowledge and skills 

  • Broaden students' global perspectives of research 

Objectives related to Goal 2: Transferrable Professional Skills 

  • Increase students' leadership skills  

  • Increase students' communication, management, and problem solving skills  

  • Increase number of interdisciplinary interactions and collaboration between students, faculty, industry/community partners 

  • Increase students' collaboration and teamwork skills 

Objectives related to Goal 3: Workforce Development 

  • Demonstrate a diversity of trainees, for both female and URM STEM students 

  • Demonstrate a high level of completion of degree 

  • Increase preparedness to enter STEM career  

  • Demonstrate a high level of job placement in STEM careers 

Objectives related to Goal 4: Institutional and National Research and Education Capacity 

  • Increase in number of interdisciplinary courses and course enrollment  

  • Increase in the number of publications, presentations, funded grants  

  • Increased collaborations 

  • Institutionalization of project activities 

Graduate fellows at Northwestern University from all STEM disciplines were encouraged to apply to this selective program, especially those underrepresented in the fields of Astronomy, Physics, Earth and Planetary Science, Electrical Engineering, and Computer Science. Over the course of the IDEAS program 10 different PhD Programs were ultimately represented:. From 2015 to 2021, IDEAS has provided funding for 26 PhD fellows who were active in the program. 13 additional students fully participated as non-funded trainees in IDEAS, 15 more students were involved to a substantive degree, and over 230 students took part in machine learning meetups and data science evenings. 

In order to fully complete the IDEAS program, each fellow had to satisfy 12 core components. These components included weekly cohort meetings, a range of coursework in data science, activities focused on data visualizations and computer programming, communication workshops, participation in citizen science projects, and an internship where they could put new skills into practice and foster professional connections. These requirements that IDEAS is comprised of were designed to be completed over the course of 4 years, but accelerated completion of the program was possible by students on shorter timelines. The technical skills taught through the coursework and bootcamps provided a robust background for the students' doctoral research, while the communication workshops and professional development opportunities helped create pathways to success in the students' careers.  Over IDEAS lifespan, the knowledge, skills, and connections fostered through the program has aided in the development of various research endeavors, published papers, conference presentations, machine learning workshops, and data science outreach events. 

Overall, evaluation findings suggest that IDEAS met its goals. A third-party evaluator conducted surveys with both students and faculty for each component of IDEAS, as well summative surveys to assess the overall success of the program. Findings indicate that the project facilitated gains in students' scientific knowledge and technical skills, participation in professional and academic activities, career interests and knowledge, and the likelihood of entering a career that utilizes interdisciplinary data science (Goal 1). Survey results suggest that the project has increased students' interest in and skills to participate in interdisciplinary research and collaborations at different levels: with university peers and with experts outside the university (Goal 2). Survey results also showed that IDEAS has contributed to developing students' leadership and communication skills, particularly in the context of their engagement with scientists in disciplines other than their own (Goal 2). Additionally, students specified that the project influenced career goals in interdisciplinary, data science-driven careers either in academia or in industry (Goal 3). Respondents indicated that the project increased institutional research and education capacity, and facilitated interdisciplinary research, contributing to the data science field (Goal 4). The overall satisfaction of the fellows and trainees with the project was high; 88% rated their satisfaction with the project as "Satisfactory" to "Very Satisfactory". By all markers, the IDEAS program has been a success for all individuals involved so far.
